Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Going back in time: using museum collections to reconstruct the history of a host shift in an invasive insect
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Interactions between insects and the plants they eat impacts biodiversity, and the introduction of a non-native species provides a unique window into the earliest stages of how these introduced insects adapt to a new food source. This research uses a wealth of historical data in museum collections to reconstruct how an invasive insect pest adapted to a native host plant over a 100-year period. By integrating fieldwork, laboratory work, and genomic data from historical and current samples, the fellow will gain insight into how invasive species adapt over time and in different environments. Better knowledge of how invasive species change to fit their new surroundings is vital for understanding evolution, as well as developing strategies for agricultural pest management. This research will also provide training for the fellow to use and contribute to undervalued museum collections, mentor individuals from underrepresented groups in field research, and create a website for public engagement in pest identification.

The fellow will investigate the morphological, behavioral, and genetic changes that accompanied adaptation to a native pine in the invasive pine sawfly Diprion similis. First introduced to North America in 1914, D. similis rapidly shifted to native White Pine, Pinus strobus. To reconstruct the history of this host shift, the fellow will combine extensive museum collections of D. similis from 3 international institutions together with sampling from contemporary populations. First, the fellow will use museum specimens and associated host data to assess morphological and behavioral change across both the native and introduced ranges over the entire history of the invasion. Second, the fellow will evaluate whether these morphological and behavioral changes are adaptive by revisiting historical collection sites and using a combination of field surveys and laboratory assays to measure host preference and host performance. Finally, the project aims to use whole-genome resequencing data from both modern and historical samples to uncover the demographic history of the North American invasion. Together, this project aims to address several longstanding questions about host specialization and rapid adaptation in invasive species, while meeting several career training goals. The fellow will become an expert in working with D. similis, as well as develop genomic skills and resources to enable use of this novel study system in an independent research position. The broader impacts of the project include student mentoring and public engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this NSF postdoctoral research fellowship was to use data generated from museum collections to reconstruct the history of an insect invasive to North America. This work was overall a success, generating novel insights into challenging biological questions, expanding the value of museum collection resources, and training the fellow in cutting edge techniques. Below is a brief summary of the main results, merit, and broader impacts of this work.

 

The focal species—the white pine sawfly: Diprion similis—arrived in North America in 1914, and quickly shifted to using the North American white pine as host. These characteristics make this species a uniquely good model for studying how species adapt to new hosts—a phenomenon responsible for much of Earth’s biodiversity. Within 110 years, this species invaded North America and adapted to using a tree host completely absent in its original range—a relatively rapid shift. ~100 years is an ideal timeframe for using museum resources, as collection records for this species are quite robust, and both genetic and morphological data should remain relatively undamaged.

 

As a result of this funding, the fellow gathered morphological and genetic data from 336 specimens of D. similis spanning from the date of the original introduction (1914) to 2022 to evaluate the adaptive history of this invasive species. The fellow led two publications with a third on the way describing the findings. The fellow began by generating data on modern specimens that he collected throughout the introduced range and publishing a reference genome. These modern data strongly indicate that D. similis arrived in North America in a single invasive wave, showing a near-total use of white pines as a host in 2021-2022. This contrasts with expectations from previous studies indicating such a strong shift in host is expected to be accompanied by multiple waves of invasion to elevate genetic diversity—an important precursor for adaptation. The fellow then moved on to analyzing historical specimens and found that while morphology had not evolved during the north American invasion, there was definitive evidence of multiple genetic introductions. We additionally found genes of interest that may have evolved to help D. similis adapt to North America. These findings illustrate the power of using historical collections to power analyses of biological events in the past. The analysis of the modern data disguised a history of multiple invasions that was likely important for successful colonization of North America. This represents a key new finding both for the fields of invasion biology as well as for developing methods to use collections infrastructure.

 

One of the key breakthroughs from this award is the successful generation of whole-genome sequences from historical specimens up to 110 years old—a strategy that has been rarely attempted with historical specimens. Previously, most historical DNA work used other techniques to generate a higher volume of DNA from a smaller portion of the genome. While this has its uses, it prevents population genomic analyses, making it impossible to answer questions such as: “how many invasions happened?” and “can we locate genes associated with invasion success?”. Here, we generated whole genome sequences from 45 specimens more than 50 years old and used them to uncover new insights into a historical invasion and locate potentially important adaptive genes. In this way, this award has created analytical methods and proof-of-concept for using museum collection infrastructure for future insights.

 

This award also accomplished its training goals of preparing the fellow for a future of independent research. The fellow learned methodological and analytical techniques for the population genomics field which he had little prior experience in. He became a world expert on Diprion similis and is leading cutting-edge research on museum genomic analyses that few in the world are currently attempting or employing. Furthermore, the fellow published a paper in the Journal of Integrated Pest Management profiling pine sawflies and outlining management strategies for limiting their economic impacts. The fellow has turned D. similis into an excellent model organism of study on biological invasions and history of adaptation. One undergraduate was trained to use and analyze museum data as a consequence of this award, and the fellow’s trajectory thanks to this award should lead to more mentorship in his future. This work was shared at 3 conferences and in 5 total talks across the award period. As a training grant, this award can be considered a resounding success.
